member.name: P:WixSharp.WixEntity.Attributes
member.summary:
Collection of Attribute/Value pairs for WiX element attributes not supported directly by Wix# objects.
You should use Attributes if you want to inject specific XML attributes for a given WiX element.
For example Hotkey attribute is not supported by Wix# but if you want them to be set in the WiX source file you may achieve this be setting WixEntity.Attributes member variable:
new Shortcut { Attributes= new { {"Hotkey", "0"} }
You can also inject attributes into WiX components "related" to the but not directly represented in the Wix# entities family. For example if you need to set a custom attribute for the WiX Component XML element you can use corresponding attributes. The only difference from the Hotkey example is the composite (column separated) key name:
new File { Attributes= new { {"Component:SharedDllRefCount", "yes"} } The code above will force the Wix# compiler to insert "SharedDllRefCount" attribute into Component XML element, which is automatically generated for the .
Currently the only supported "related" attribute is Component.

member.name: P:WixSharp.WixEntity.AttributesDefinition
member.summary:
Optional attributes of the WiX Element (e.g. Secure:YesNoPath) expressed as a string KeyValue pairs (e.g. "StartOnInstall=Yes; Sequence=1").
OptionalAttributes just redirects all access calls to the member.
You can also use to keep the code cleaner.

member.name: P:WixSharp.WixEntity.Id
member.summary:
Gets or sets the Id value of the .
This value is used as a Id for the corresponding WiX XML element.
If the value is not specified explicitly by the user the Wix# compiler generates it automatically insuring its uniqueness.
Note: The ID auto-generation is triggered on the first access (evaluation) and in order to make the id allocation deterministic the compiler resets ID generator just before the build starts. However if you accessing any auto-id before the Build*() is called you can it interferes with the ID auto generation and eventually lead to the WiX ID duplications. To prevent this from happening either:\n" - Avoid evaluating the auto-generated IDs values before the call to Build*() - Set the IDs (to be evaluated) explicitly - Prevent resetting auto-ID generator by setting WixEntity.DoNotResetIdGenerator to true";

member.name: T:WixSharp.AutoElements
member.summary:
Automatically insert elements required for satisfy odd MSI restrictions.
- You must set KeyPath you install in the user profile.
- You must use a registry key under HKCU as component's KeyPath, not a file.
- The Component element cannot have multiple key path set.
- The project must have at least one directory element.
- All directories installed in the user profile must have corresponding RemoveDirectory elements.
...
The MSI always wants registry keys as the key paths for per-user components. It has to do with the way profiles work with advertised content in enterprise deployments. The fact that you do not want to install any registry doesn't matter. MSI is the boss.
The following link is a good example of the technique: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16119708/component-testcomp-installs-to-user-profile-it-must-use-a-registry-key-under-hk

member.name: F:WixSharp.AutoElements.DisableAutoCreateFolder
member.summary:
The disable automatic insertion of CreateFolder element. Required for: NativeBootstrapper, EmbeddedMultipleActions, EmptyDirectories, InstallDir, Properties, ReleaseFolder, Shortcuts and WildCardFiles samples.
Can also be managed by disabling ICE validation via Light.exe command line arguments.

member.name: F:WixSharp.AutoElements.DisableAutoUserProfileRegistry
member.summary:
The disable automatic insertion of user profile registry elements. Required for: AllInOne, ConditionalInstallation, CustomAttributes, ReleaseFolder, Shortcuts, Shortcuts (advertised), Shortcuts-2, WildCardFiles samples.
Can also be managed by disabling ICE validation via Light.exe command line arguments.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Bootstrapper.Bundle.DisableRollback
member.summary: The disable rollbackSpecifies whether the bundle will attempt to rollback packages executed in the chain. If "yes" is specified then when a vital package fails to install only that package will rollback and the chain will stop with the error. The default is "no" which indicates all packages executed during the chain will be rolldback to their previous state when a vital package fails.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Bootstrapper.Bundle.DisableSystemRestore
member.summary: Specifies whether the bundle will attempt to create a system restore point when executing the chain. If "yes" is specified then a system restore point will not be created. The default is "no" which indicates a system restore point will be created when the bundle is installed, uninstalled, repaired, modified, etc. If the system restore point cannot be created, the bundle will log the issue and continue.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Bootstrapper.Bundle.Copyright
member.summary: The legal copyright found in the version resources of final bundle executable. If this attribute is not provided the copyright will be set to "Copyright (c) [Bundle/@Manufacturer]. All rights reserved.".

member.name: F:WixSharp.Bootstrapper.Bundle.AboutUrl
member.summary: A URL for more information about the bundle to display in Programs and Features (also known as Add/Remove Programs).

member.name: F:WixSharp.Bootstrapper.Bundle.Compressed
member.summary: Whether Packages and Payloads not assigned to a container should be added to the default attached container or if they should be external. The default is yes.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Bootstrapper.Bundle.Condition
member.summary: The condition of the bundle. If the condition is not met, the bundle will refuse to run. Conditions are checked before the bootstrapper application is loaded (before detect), and thus can only reference built-in variables such as variables which indicate the version of the OS.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Bootstrapper.Bundle.DisableRemove
member.summary: Determines whether the bundle can be removed via the Programs and Features (also known as Add/Remove Programs). If the value is "yes" then the "Uninstall" button will not be displayed. The default is "no" which ensures there is an "Uninstall" button to remove the bundle. If the "DisableModify" attribute is also "yes" or "button" then the bundle will not be displayed in Progams and Features and another mechanism (such as registering as a related bundle addon) must be used to ensure the bundle can be removed.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Bootstrapper.Bundle.DisableModify
member.summary: Determines whether the bundle can be modified via the Programs and Features (also known as Add/Remove Programs). If the value is "button" then Programs and Features will show a single "Uninstall/Change" button. If the value is "yes" then Programs and Features will only show the "Uninstall" button". If the value is "no", the default, then a "Change" button is shown. See the DisableRemove attribute for information how to not display the bundle in Programs and Features.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Bootstrapper.Bundle.HelpTelephone

member.name: F:WixSharp.Bootstrapper.ExePackage.DetectCondition
member.summary: A condition that determines if the package is present on the target system. This condition can use built-in variables and variables returned by searches. This condition is necessary because Windows doesn't provide a method to detect the presence of an ExePackage. Burn uses this condition to determine how to treat this package during a bundle action; for example, if this condition is false or omitted and the bundle is being installed, Burn will install this package.

member.name: M:WixSharp.CommonTasks.Tasks.BuildBootstrapper(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Builds the bootstrapper.
member.param: The prerequisite file.
The primary setup file.
The output (bootsrtapper) file.

The prerequisite registry key value.
This value is used to determine if the PrerequisiteFile should be launched.
This value must comply with the following pattern: <RegistryHive>:<KeyPath>:<ValueName>. PrerequisiteRegKeyValue = @"HKLM:Software\My Company\My Product:Installed"; Existence of the specified registry value at runtime is interpreted as an indication of the PrerequisiteFile has been alreday installed. Thus bootstrapper will execute PrimaryFile without launching PrerequisiteFile first.

The flag which allows you to disable verification of PrerequisiteRegKeyValue after the prerequisite setup is completed.
Normally if bootstrapper checks if PrerequisiteRegKeyValue/> exists straight after the prerequisite installation and starts the primary setup only if it does.
It is possible to instruct bootstrapper to continue with the primary setup regardless of the prerequisite installation outcome. This can be done by setting DoNotPostVerifyPrerequisite to true (default is false)
The optional arguments for the bootstrapper compiler.
member.returns: Path to the built bootstrapper file. Returns null if bootstrapper cannot be built.
member.example:
The following is an example of building bootstrapper Setup.msi for deploying .NET along with the MyProduct.msi file.
WixSharp.CommonTasks.Tasks.BuildBootstrapper( @"C:\downloads\dotnetfx.exe", "MainProduct.msi", "setup.exe", @"HKLM:Software\My Company\My Product:Installed" false, "");

member.name: M:WixSharp.CommonTasks.Tasks.DigitalySign(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Applies digital signature to a file (e.g. msi, exe, dll) with MS SignTool.exe utility.
member.param: The file to sign.
Specify the signing certificate in a file. If this file is a PFX with a password, the password may be supplied with the password parameter.
The timestamp server's URL. If this option is not present (pass to null), the signed file will not be timestamped. A warning is generated if timestamping fails.
The password to use when opening the PFX file. Should be null if no password required.
Extra arguments to pass to the SignTool.exe utility.

The optional ';' separated list of directories where SignTool.exe can be located. If this parameter is not specified WixSharp will try to locate the SignTool in the built-in well-known locations (system PATH)
member.returns: Exit code of the SignTool.exe process.
member.example:
The following is an example of signing Setup.msi file.
WixSharp.CommonTasks.Tasks.DigitalySign( "Setup.msi", "MyCert.pfx", "http://timestamp.verisign.com/scripts/timstamp.dll", "MyPassword", null);

member.name: M:WixSharp.CommonTasks.Tasks.DigitalySign(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Applies digital signature to a file (e.g. msi, exe, dll) with MS SignTool.exe utility.
If you need to specify extra SignTool.exe parameters or the location of the tool use the overloaded DigitalySign signature
member.param: The file to sign.
Specify the signing certificate in a file. If this file is a PFX with a password, the password may be supplied with the password parameter.
The timestamp server's URL. If this option is not present, the signed file will not be timestamped. A warning is generated if timestamping fails.
The password to use when opening the PFX file.
member.returns: Exit code of the SignTool.exe process.
member.example:
The following is an example of signing Setup.msi file.
WixSharp.CommonTasks.Tasks.DigitalySign( "Setup.msi", "MyCert.pfx", "http://timestamp.verisign.com/scripts/timstamp.dll", "MyPassword");

member.name: M:WixSharp.CommonTasks.Tasks.SetClrPrerequisite(WixSharp.Project,System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Binds the LaunchCondition to the automatically created REQUIRED_NET property which is set to the value of the Software\Microsoft\NET Framework Setup\NDP\{version}\Install registry entry.
It is a single step equivalent of the "Wix# Samples\LaunchConditions" sample.
Note that the value of the version parameter is a precise sub-key of the corresponding 'Install' registry entry (e.g. as in 'HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\NET Framework Setup\NDP\v4.0\Client\Install').
The typical values are:
v2.0.50727
v3.0
v3.5
v4\Client
v4\Full
v4.0\Client
...
member.param: The project.
The sub-key of the registry entry of the sub-key of the corresponding registry version of .NET to be checked.
The error message to be displayed if .NET version is not present.

member.name: M:WixSharp.CommonTasks.Tasks.SetNetFxPrerequisite(WixSharp.Project,System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Binds the LaunchCondition to the version condition based on WiXNetFxExtension properties.
The typical conditions are:
NETFRAMEWORK20="#1"
NETFRAMEWORK40FULL="#1"
NETFRAMEWORK35="#1"
NETFRAMEWORK30_SP_LEVEL and NOT NETFRAMEWORK30_SP_LEVEL='#0'
... The full list of names and values can be found here http://wixtoolset.org/documentation/manual/v3/customactions/wixnetfxextension.html
member.param: The project.
Condition expression.
The error message to be displayed if .NET version is not present.

member.name: M:WixSharp.CommonTasks.Tasks.SetConfigAttribute(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Sets the value of the attribute value in the .NET application configuration file according the specified XPath expression.
This simple routine is to be used for the customization of the installed config files (e.g. in the deferred custom actions).
member.param: The configuration file.
The element XPath value. It should include the attribute name.
The value to be set to the attribute.
member.example:
The following is an example demonstrates this simple technique:
Tasks.SetConfigAttribute(configFile, "//configuration/appSettings/add[@key='AppName']/@value", "My App");

member.summary:
Sets the value of the attribute value in the .NET application configuration file according the specified XPath expression.
This simple routine is to be used for the customization of the installed config files (e.g. in the deferred custom actions).
member.param: The configuration file element.
The element XPath value. It should include the attribute name.
The value to be set to the attribute.
member.example:
The following is an example demonstrates this simple technique:
XDocument.Load(configFile).Root .SetConfigAttribute("//configuration/appSettings/add[@key='AppName']/@value", "My App") .SetConfigAttribute(... .SetConfigAttribute(... .Document.Save(configFile);

member.name: T:WixSharp.DialogSequence
member.summary:
Simple class that defines custom UI (WiX UI element). This is a specialized version of class designed to allow simple customization of the dialogs sequence without the introduction of any custom dialogs. The following is an example demonstrates how to skip License Agreement dialog, which is otherwise displayed between Welcome and InstallDir dialogs.
project.CustomUI = new DialogSequence() .On(Dialogs.WelcomeDlg, Buttons.Next, new ShowDialog(Dialogs.InstallDirDlg)) .On(Dialogs.InstallDirDlg, Buttons.Back, new ShowDialog(Dialogs.WelcomeDlg));

member.name: T:WixSharp.CustomUI
member.summary:
Defines custom UI (WiX UI element). This class is to be used to define the customization of the standard MSI UI. The usual scenario of the customization is the injection of the custom into the sequence of the standard dialogs. This can be accomplished by defining the custom dialog as . Such a can be edited with the Visual Studio form designer.
When is complete it can be converted into with the () call. And at compile time Wix# compiler converts into the final WiX UI element XML definition.
While it is possible to construct instance manually it is preferred to use Factory methods of (e.g. BuildPostLicenseDialogUI) for this.
project.UI = WUI.WixUI_Common; project.CustomUI = CustomUIBuilder.BuildPostLicenseDialogUI(productActivationDialog, onNextActions: new DialogAction[]{ new ExecueteCustomAction ("ValidateLicenceKey"), new ShowDialog(Dialogs.InstallDirDlg, "SERIALNUMBER_VALIDATED = \"TRUE\"")});

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.Expand(System.String)
member.summary:
Replaces all Wix# predefined string constants (Environment Constants) in the Wix# directory path with their WiX equivalents and escapes all WiX illegal characters (e.g. space character).
It also replaces all "illegal" characters (e.g. !,\) with '_' character to allow the path value to be used as a WiX Id XML attribute. The following is an example of expanding directory name paths.
@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product" @"ProgramFilesFolder\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product" @"[ProgramFilesFolder]\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product"
For the list of supported constants analyses WixSharp.Compiler.EnvironmentConstantsMapping.Keys.
member.param: The Wix# directory path.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.ContainsWixConstants(System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether the string contains WiX constants (values enclosed into square brackets).
member.param: The data.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.Map64Dirs(System.String)
member.summary:
Maps the Wix# constants included in path into their x64 equivalents.
For example %ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product should be preprocessed into %ProgramFiles64%\My Company\My Product
member.param: The path.

member.summary:
Replaces all Wix# predefined string constants (Environment Constants) in the Wix# directory path with their WiX equivalents and escapes all WiX illegal characters (e.g. space character).
The following is an example of expanding directory name paths.
@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product" @"ProgramFilesFolder\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product" @"[ProgramFilesFolder]\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product"
For the list of supported constants analyse WixSharp.Compiler.EnvironmentConstantsMapping.Keys.
member.param: The Wix# directory path.

member.name: T:WixSharp.ManagedAction
member.summary:
Defines WiX Managed CustomAction.
Managed CustomAction can be defined either in the Wix# script or in the external assembly or C# file. The only requirements for any C# method to be qualified for being Managed CustomAcyion is to have DTF Action signature public static ActionResult MyManagedAction(Session session), and be marked with [CustomAction] attribute.
If Managed CustomAction depends on any assembly, which will not be registered with GAC on the target system such assembly needs to be listed in the .
often needs to be executed with the elevated privileges. Thus after instantiation it will have set to false and set to Execute.deferred to allow elevating.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ManagedAction.UsesProperties
member.summary:
Comma separated list of properties which the custom action is intended to use. Set this property if you are implementing the deferred action.
Deferred custom actions cannot access any session property as the session is terminated at the time of the action execution (limitation of MSI). The standard way of overcoming this limitation is to create a new custom action for setting the property, set the property name to the name of the deferred action, set the property value to the specially formatted map, schedule the execution of the custom action and access the mapped properties only via .
All this can be done in a single hit with Wix# as it fully automates creation of the all mapping infrastructure.

remarks.para: Note that you don't even have to specify UsesProperties = "INSTALLDIR" as by default Wix# always maps INSTALLDIR and UILevel for all deferred managed actions. The default mapping is controlled by .
It is also possible to map the 'deferred' properties in the typical WiX way:

member.name: F:WixSharp.ManagedAction.DefaultUsesProperties
member.summary:
The default properties mapped for use with the deferred custom actions. See for the details.
The default value is "INSTALLDIR,UILevel"

member.name: F:WixSharp.Project.EmitConsistentPackageId
member.summary:
Indicates whether compiler should emit consistent package Id (package code). Set EmitConsistentPackageId to 'false' (default value) if you want the WiX compilers automatically generate a new package code for each new .msi file built. Or set it to 'true' if you want Wix# to auto generate a unique consistent package code for a given combination of the product code, product version and product upgrade code.
WiX package code generation policy discourages the use of this attribute as it is a primary MSI identifier used to distinguish packages in ARP. Thus WiX tools always auto-generate the code for each build. This in turn makes it impossible to rebuild a truly identical MSIs from the same WiX code even with the same set of product code, version and upgrade code.
This very artificial limitation has severe practical impact. For example if a specific MSI file is lost it cannot be recreated even if the original source code that was used to built the lost MSI is available.
From another hand Wix# encourages using a singe GUID (Project.GUID) as a primary identifier of the product. Thus all other MSI identifiers can be derived by the compiler from the unique combination of this GUID and the product version. This also included generation of the package Id attribute controlled by the EmitConsistentPackageId.
Wix# does not changes the WiX default package code generation it just gives the opportunity to control it when required.

This method is called by during the compilation. However it might be convenient to call it before the compilation if any files matching the wild card mask need to be handled in special way (e.g. shortcuts created). See WildCard Files example. should be called only after is set. Otherwise wild card paths may not be resolved correctly.

This value uniquely identifies the software product being installed.

This value should not be confused with MSI Product.Id, which is in fact not an identifier of the product but rather an identifier of the product particular version. MSI uses UpgradeCode as a common identification of the product regardless of it's version.

member.name: T:WixSharp.Merge
member.summary:
Defines MergeModule to be embedded into MSI.
Note that WiX syntax allows Merge element to belong to the Product element. However the documentation (WiX v3.0.4917.0) explicitly requires it to be nested inside of the Directory element (even if there is no neither technical nor logical reason for this). Thus Wix# simply follows the WiX convention.

member.name: T:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper
member.summary:
Defines native (un-managed) bootstrapper. The primary usage of is to build bootstrappers for automatically installing .NET for executing MSIs containing managed Custom Actions ().
NativeBootstrapper is subject to the following limitations:
Only Win32 native bootstrapper can be built.
Only one Prerequisite cen be defined.

member.name: M:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.Build
member.summary: Builds bootstrapper file.
member.returns: Path to the built bootstrapper file. Returns null if bootstrapper cannot be built.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.PrerequisiteFile
member.summary: Gets or sets the prerequisite file.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.PrimaryFile
member.summary: Gets or sets the primary setup file.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.PrerequisiteRegKeyValue
member.summary:
Gets or sets the prerequisite registry key value. This value is used to determine if the should be launched.
This value must comply with the following pattern: <RegistryHive>:<KeyPath>:<ValueName>. PrerequisiteRegKeyValue = @"HKLM:Software\My Company\My Product:Installed"; Existence of the specified registry value at runtime is interpreted as an indication that the has been alreday installed. Thus bootstrapper will execute without launching first.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.OutputFile
member.summary: Gets or sets the output file (bootsrtapper) name.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.DoNotPostVerifyPrerequisite
member.summary:
Gets or sets the flag which allows you to disable verification of after the prerequisite setup is completed.
Normally if bootstrapper checkes if exists stright after the prerequisite installation and starts the primary setup only if it does.
It is possible to instruct bootstrapper to continue with the primary setup regardless of the prerequisite installation outcome. This can be done by setting DoNotPostVerifyPrerequisite to true (default is false)
member.value: The do not post verify prerequisite.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.OptionalArguments
member.summary: Gets or sets the optional arguments for the bootstrapper compiler.

member.name: T:WixSharp.Binary
member.summary:
Defines binary file to be embedded into MSI (Binary table).
You can use this class to embed any file (e.g. exe, dll, image) to be used during the installation. Note that none of the binary files are installed on the target system. They are just available at installation time for using CustomActions.
member.example:
The following is an example of embedding CRTSetup.msi file into MSI for further use in InstallCRTAction .
var project = new Project("MyProduct",
new Dir(@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product", new File("readme.txt")), ...
new Binary("CRTSetup.msi"), new ManagedAction("InstallCRTAction", ...

member.name: T:WixSharp.Condition
member.summary:
Defines WiX Condition. Condition is normally associated with CustomActions or WiX elements (e.g. Shortcut).
is nothing else but an XML friendly string wrapper, containing some predefined (commonly used) condition values. You can either use one of the predefined condition values (static members) or define your by specifying full string representation of the required WiX condition when calling the constructor or static method Create.
member.example:
The following is an example of initializing the Shortcut. with custom value INSTALLDESKTOPSHORTCUT="yes" and the InstalledFileAction. with perefined value NOT_Installed:
var project = new Project("My Product", ... new Dir(@"%Desktop%", new WixSharp.Shortcut("MyApp", "[INSTALL_DIR]MyApp.exe", "") { Condition = new Condition("INSTALLDESKTOPSHORTCUT=\"yes\"") }), new InstalledFileAction("MyApp.exe", "", Return.check, When.After, Step.InstallFinalize, Condition.NOT_Installed), ...

member.name: T:WixSharp.Dir
member.summary:
Defines directory to be installed on target system.
Use this class to define file/directory structure of the deployment solution.
You can use predefined Wix# environment constants for well-known installation locations. They are directly mapped to the corresponding WiX constants:
Wix# - WiX
%WindowsFolder% - [WindowsFolder]
%ProgramFiles% - [ProgramFilesFolder]
%ProgramMenu% - [ProgramMenuFolder]
%AppDataFolder% - [AppDataFolder]
%CommonFilesFolder% - [CommonFilesFolder]
%LocalAppDataFolder% - [LocalAppDataFolder]
%ProgramFiles64Folder% - [ProgramFiles64Folder]
%System64Folder% - [System64Folder]
%SystemFolder% - [SystemFolder]
%TempFolder% - [TempFolder]
%Desktop% - [DesktopFolder]

members.member:
Defines all files of a given source directory and all subdirectories to be installed on target system.
Use this class to define files to be automatically included into the deployment solution if their name matches specified wildcard character pattern ().
You can use to exclude certain files from setup if required.
This class is a logical equivalent of except it also analyses all files in all subdirectories. excludes files in subdirectories.
Note that all files matching wildcard are resolved into absolute path thus it may not always be suitable if the Wix# script is to be compiled into WiX XML source only (Compiler.). Though it is not a problem at all if the Wix# script is compiled into MSI file (Compiler.). b The following is an example of defining installation files with wildcard character pattern.
new Project("MyProduct", new Dir(@"%ProgramFiles%\MyCompany\MyProduct", new Files(@"Release\Bin\*.*"), ...

Wildcard pattern(s) for files to be excluded from MSI (e.g. new Files(typical, @"Release\Bin\*.dll", "*.Test.dll", "*.UnitTest.dll")).

member.name: T:WixSharp.DirFiles
member.summary:
Defines files of a given source directory to be installed on target system. Note that files in subdirectories are not included.
Use this class to define files to be automatically included into the deployment solution if their name matches specified wildcard character pattern ().
You can use to exclude certain files from setup if required.
This class is a logical equivalent of except that it analyses files in a single directory.
member.remarks: Note that all files matching the wildcard are resolved into absolute paths, so it may not always be suitable if the Wix# script is to be compiled into WiX XML source only (Compiler.). This is not a problem if the Wix# script is compiled into MSI file (Compiler.).
member.example:
The following is an example of defining installation files with a wildcard character pattern.
new Project("MyProduct", new Dir(@"%ProgramFiles%\MyCompany\MyProduct", new DirFiles(@"Release\Bin\*.*"), new Dir("GlobalResources", new DirFiles(@"Release\Bin\GlobalResources\*.*")), new Dir("Images", new DirFiles(@"Release\Bin\Images\*.*")), ...

member.param: The relative path to directory source directory. It must include wildcard pattern for files to be included into MSI (new DirFiles(@"Release\Bin\*.*")).

member.param: The relative path to directory source directory. It must include wildcard pattern for files to be included into MSI (e.g. new DirFiles(@"Release\Bin\*.*")).
Wildcard pattern(s) for files to be excluded from MSI (e.g. new DirFiles(typical, @"Release\Bin\*.dll", "*.Test.dll", "*.UnitTest.dll")).

member.name: T:WixSharp.InstalledFileAction
member.summary: Defines WiX InstalledFileAction for executing installed file.
member.example:
The following is an example of using InstalledFileAction to run installed executable Registrator.exe with different arguments depending in installation type (install/uninstall):
var project = new Project("My Product",
new Dir(@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product",
new File(binaries, @"AppFiles\MyApp.exe", new WixSharp.Shortcut("MyApp", @"%ProgramMenu%\My Company\My Product"), new WixSharp.Shortcut("MyApp", @"%Desktop%")),
new File(binaries, @"AppFiles\Registrator.exe"),
new InstalledFileAction("Registrator.exe", "", Return.check, When.After, Step.InstallFinalize, Condition.NOT_Installed),
new InstalledFileAction("Registrator.exe", "/u", Return.check, When.Before, Step.InstallFinalize, Condition.Installed), ...
Compiler.BuildMsi(project);

member.name: T:WixSharp.PropertyRef
member.summary:
Defines reference to the Wix custom property.
Sometimes it desirable to access WiX properties defined in the extension modules. is designed for such cases. You can use it as an ordinary WiX property but you do not need to set it up (e.g. define initial value) as it is already done in the corresponding extension module.
In a way PropertyRef is similar to C++ #include as it makes possible to access some entities defined in the external modules.
member.remarks: inherits from because of their logical relationship and usability pattern, not because of any "Parent/Child" connection.

member.name: T:WixSharp.Property
member.summary:
Defines WiX custom property.
Traditional property usage involves defining the property by instantiating the class (in the structure) and then setting it from CustomAction (e.g. ).

member.name: T:WixSharp.RegValueProperty
member.summary:
Defines WiX custom property assigned by MSI runtime during the installation to the RegistrySearch result.
is used to set a property from the registry value when accessing the registry is inconvenient for a custom action.
RegistrySearch returns raw data thus data will always contain prefix indicating data type:
DWORD: Starts with '#' optionally followed by '+' or '-'.
REG_BINARY: Starts with '#x' and the installer converts and saves each hexadecimal digit (nibble) as an ASCII character prefixed by '#x'.
REG_EXPAND_SZ: Starts with '#%'.
REG_MULTI_SZ: Starts with '[~]' and ends with '[~]'.
REG_SZ: No prefix, but if the first character of the registry value is '#', the installer escapes the character by prefixing it with another '#'.
member.remarks: In Wix# the preferred way of setting a property value is assigning it from . However may not be an available option if the target system does not have .NET installed. In such cases should be used.
member.example:
The following is an example of installing DotNET Manual.txt file only if .NET v2.0 is installed.
var project = new Project("MyProduct", new Dir(@"%ProgramMenu%\My Company\My Product", new File(@"Files\DotNET Manual.txt") { Condition = new Condition("NETFRAMEWORK20=\"#1\"") }, ... new RegValueProperty("NETFRAMEWORK20", RegistryHive.LocalMachine, @"Software\Microsoft\NET Framework Setup\NDP\v2.0.50727", "Install", "not_defined"),

member.summary: Defines service installer for the file being installed. It encapsulates functionality provided by ServiceInstall and ServiceConfig WiX elements.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with properties/fields initialized with specified parameters.
member.param: The name.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ServiceInstaller.ErrorControl
member.summary: The error control associated with the service startup. The default value is SvcErrorControl.normal.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ServiceInstaller.StartType
member.summary: Defines the way service starts. The default value is SvcStartType.auto.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ServiceInstaller.DisplayName
member.summary: The display name of the service as it is listed in the Control Panel. If not specified the name of the service will be used instead.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ServiceInstaller.Description
member.summary: The description of the service as it is listed in the Control Panel.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ServiceInstaller.Type
member.summary: The type of the service (e.g. kernel/system driver, process). The default value is SvcType.ownProcess.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ServiceInstaller.StartOn
member.summary:
Associates 'start service' action with the specific service installation event. The default value is SvcEvent.Install. Meaning "start the service when it is installed".
Set this member to null if you don't want to start the service at any stage of the installation.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ServiceInstaller.StopOn
member.summary:
Associates 'stop service' action with the specific service installation event. The default value is SvcEvent.InstallUninstall_Wait. Meaning "stop the service when it is being installed and uninstalled and wait for the action completion".
Set this member to null if you don't want to stop the service at any stage of the installation.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ServiceInstaller.RemoveOn
member.summary:
Associates 'remove service' action with the specific service installation event. The default value is SvcEvent.Uninstall. Meaning "remove the service when it is uninstalled".
Set this member to null if you don't want to remove the service at any stage of the installation.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ServiceInstaller.DependsOn
member.summary:
Semicolon separated list of the names of the external service the service being installed depends on. It supposed to be names (not the display names) of a previously installed services.
For example: DependsOn = "Dnscache;Dhcp"

member.name: T:WixSharp.SvcEvent
member.summary: Defines details of the setup event triggering the service actions to be performed during the service installation.

member.name: F:WixSharp.SvcEvent.Type
member.summary: Specifies when the service action occur. It can be one of the values.

member.name: F:WixSharp.SvcEvent.Wait
member.summary: The flag indicating if after triggering the service action the setup should wait until te action is completed.

member.name: F:WixSharp.SvcEvent.Install
member.summary: Predefined instance of with Type set to and Wait to false. It triggers the action during the service installation without waiting for the completion.

member.name: F:WixSharp.SvcEvent.Install_Wait
member.summary: Predefined instance of with Type set to and Wait to true. It triggers the action during the service installation with waiting for the completion.

member.name: F:WixSharp.SvcEvent.Uninstall
member.summary: Predefined instance of with Type set to and Wait to false. It triggers the action during the service installation without waiting for the completion.

member.name: F:WixSharp.SvcEvent.Uninstall_Wait
member.summary: Predefined instance of with Type set to and Wait to true. It triggers the action during the service installation with waiting for the completion.

member.summary: Predefined instance of with Type set to and Wait to false. It triggers the action during the service installation without waiting for the completion.

member.name: F:WixSharp.SvcEvent.InstallUninstall_Wait
member.summary: Predefined instance of with Type set to and Wait to true. It triggers the action during the service installation with waiting for the completion.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Step.InstallExecuteAgain
member.summary: The InstallExecuteAgain action runs a script containing all operations in the action sequence since either the start of the installation or the last InstallExecuteAgain action or the last InstallExecute action. The InstallExecute action updates the system without ending the transaction. InstallExecuteAgain performs the same operation as the InstallExecute action but should only be used after InstallExecute.

member.name: T:WixSharp.MajorUpgradeStrategy
member.summary: This class defines the Major Upgrade scenario.

member.name: F:WixSharp.MajorUpgradeStrategy.UpgradeVersions
member.summary:
Range of versions which should be automatically uninstalled during the installation of the product MSI being built.
Typically these are all versions older then the version being installed.

member.name: F:WixSharp.MajorUpgradeStrategy.PreventDowngradingVersions
member.summary:
Range of versions, which should not be automatically uninstalled during the installation of the product MSI being built.
Typically these are all versions newer then the version being installed (downgrade scenario).

member.name: F:WixSharp.MajorUpgradeStrategy.RemoveExistingProductAfter
member.summary:
Step, which determines when the RemoveExistingProducts standard action is to be performed.
The default value is InstallFinalize.

member.name: F:WixSharp.MajorUpgradeStrategy.NewerProductInstalledErrorMessage
member.summary: Error message to be displayed if setup is aborted because of restricted downgrade attempt (see ).

member.name: F:WixSharp.MajorUpgradeStrategy.Default
member.summary: Default . Ensures that all older versions of the product are automatically uninstalled and if a newer version is detected, "Newer version already installed" message is displayed.

member.name: T:WixSharp.VersionRange
member.summary:
This class represents a range of product versions. It is designed to be used for Major/Minor upgrade scenarios in conjunction with Upgrade strategy classes (e.g. ).
Version is represented as a string to allow for predefined value %this%, which means "version of the product MSI being built".
This class includes predefined ranges for common upgrade scenarios.

member.summary:

If "%this%" is used the Minimum value will set to the version of the product MSI being built.

member.name: T:WixSharp.WebSite
member.summary: This class defines website attributes. It is a close equivalent of WebSite WiX element.

member.name: F:WixSharp.WebSite.Description
member.summary: This is the name of the web site that will show up in the IIS management console.

member.name: F:WixSharp.WebSite.InstallWebSite
member.summary:
Indicates if the WebSite is to be installed (created on IIS) or existing WebSite should be used to install the corresponding WebApplication. The default value is false
Developers should be aware of the WebSite installation model imposed by WiX/MSI and use carefully.
If value is set to false the parent WebApplication () will be installed in the brand new (freshly created) WebSite or in the existing one if a site with the same address/port combination already exists on IIS). The undesirable side affect of this deployment scenario is that if the existing WebSite was used to install the WebApplication it will be deleted on IIS during uninstallation even if this WebSite has other WebApplications installed.
The "safer" option is to set value to true (default value). In this case the WebApplication will be installed in an existing WebSite with matching address/port. If the match is not found the installation will fail. During the uninstallation only installed WebApplication will be removed from IIS.

member.summary: Creates the key, if absent, when the parent component is installed then remove the key with all its values and subkeys when the parent component is uninstalled.

member.name: F:WixSharp.RegistryKeyAction.none
member.summary: Does nothing; this element is used merely in WiX authoring for organization and does nothing to the final output.
